out using the PE Biosystems Prism 7700 (PE Biosystems, Foster City, CA).

char: 2; name: H9252; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❷ char: 2; name: H9252; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❷ char: 2; name: H9252; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary
--actin amplifications, forward and reverse primers were
accompanied by a TaqMan probe nestled between the primers. The probe
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
ffluorescent dye, which was cleaved and
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
eexonuclease activity of AmpliTaq Gold polymerase
during primer extension. The freed fluorescent signals were detected by a
CCD camera, allowing real-time accumulation of amplification signals at
each cycle. An increase in fluorescence signal was possible only if the tar-
get sequence had triple primer and probe sequence complementarity (all
reagents PE Biosystems, Foster City, CA).
The GFP product was 72 bp and the
char: 2; name: H9252; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❷
char: 2; name: H9252; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❷
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
molecule attached via a linker arm and a 5
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
eend of the probe was blocked to prevent extension
of the probe during PCR. The GFP primer and probe sequences were
designed with Primer Express software (PE Biosystems, Foster City, CA): for-
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹

char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹ char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 2; name: H9252; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❷
Foster City, CA) were as follows: forward primer (5
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
char: 4; name: H11032; f: Universal-GreekwithMathPi; fn: BFHKPM+Universal-GreekwithMathPi; e: Dictionary ❹
SYBR Green real-time PCR of GFP standards was also carried out for
comparison with probe. To prevent PCR carryover contamination, dUTP
substituted for dTTP during PCR such that all previously amplified tem-
plates containing dUTP would be cleaved by uracil
which also degraded any misprimed, nonspecific products during the 50
incubation step before amplification. The PCR cycle conditions were 50
CC for 10 min, followed by 40 cycles of 95
Plasmid DNA, vector, and cell line.
CA) encodes a red-shifted variant of wild-type GFP optimized for brighter flu-
orescence and higher expression in mammalian cells with excitation maxi-
mum at 488 nm and emission maximum at 507 nm. Expression is controlled
by the human cytomegalovirus (CMV) immediate early promoter, enhancer
region, and TATA box. For propagation in
competent cells. The plasmid DNA was
purified using a plasmid maxi prep, according to the manufacturer
tions (Qiagen, Valencia, CA). Lipofectamine reagent (Gibco BRL, Rockville,
MD) is a 3:1 (w/w) liposome formulation of the polycationic lipid 2,3-dio-
octadecenyloxy)-1-propanaminium trifluoroacetate), and the neutral lipid
dioleoyl phosphatidylethanolamine (DOPE) in membrane filtered water. Each
molecule of DOSPA has five positive charges.
C3A hepatoblastoma cell line (ATCC) was derived from HepG2, an
epithelial cell line originated from a 15-year-old male Caucasian. It was cul-
tured in modified essential medium (MEM) supplemented with 10% fetal
bovine serum (FBS; both reagents from ATCC), at 37
antibody against SV40 large T-antigen (Chemicon, Temecula, CA) con-
firmed that C3A was SV40-negative and unable to replicate pEGFP-C1 plas-
Corning plates (VWR, Boston, MA) were washed once with serum-free
medium (SFM). DNA-lipid complexes were added to cells and re-incubated.
Transfection was interrupted with extracellular plasmids diluted and
removed by double PBS washes, followed by cellular trypsinization, cen-
trifugation, and a third PBS wash. Nuclei isolation followed a standard pro-
tocol whereby 0.5% (v/v) NP-40 in a buffer supplemented with 10 mM
was twice used to achieve cell lysis and
the nuclear pellet centrifuged and purified away from supernatant that
contained cytosolic plasmids and cellular debris [40]. DNA purification
from either purified nuclei or whole cells proceeded with Triton X-100,
RNase, Proteinase K, and phenol: chloroform: isoamylalcohol (25:24:1);
DNA was precipitated with ethanol and 0.3 M sodium acetate (all reagents
We thank Tom Wickham (GenVec, Inc.) for helpful comments and sugges-
tions. This work was supported by the National Science Foundation
Engineering Research Center program and a Whitaker Foundation Graduate
